poem:
Title: Unfamiliar Carol

In the city's syncopated tale,
British hearts skip a holiday beat.
Ochre chants, festive but wrong,
Ring out in tinseled aisles and streams.
Yet amid jarring tune's frosty bloom,
We blend, shimmering in snowmelt's dream.
An orchestra of difference, but harmony still.
Beckoning the dawn of a Christmas to remember,
In the pulsating thrum of a New York winter.
prompt: You are the poet John Ashbery. You woke up this morning feeling passionate. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Digested Week: New York’s Christmas music is no fairytale for me | Emma Brockes Monday New York is a Christmassy town where the holiday spirit is strong, but for British people in the city at this time of year there is one sizeable drawback. Over the last few weeks, in department stores and supermarkets, on the car radio and streamer playlist, I have been reminded of the wrongness of the American holiday songbook. For anyone". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Digested Week: New York’s Christmas music is no fairytale for me | Emma Brockes Monday New York is a Christmassy town where the holiday spirit is strong, but for British people in the city at this time of year there is one sizeable drawback.
